honesty.definition: Being truthful and sincere in words and actions, even when it might be difficult or uncomfortable
teaching_examples: Admitting when you don't know something rather than pretending
Giving accurate feedback even when it's not what someone wants to hear
Taking responsibility for mistakes instead of covering them up
honesty.why_important: Trust is the foundation of all relationships and collaboration

commitment.binary_choice: Honor your commitments, or break your promises
commitment.principle: Reliability earns respect and maintains relationships
commitment.definition: Following through on promises and obligations you have made to others
teaching_examples: Arriving on time when you've agreed to meet someone
Completing work by the deadline you promised
Keeping confidential information private when asked
commitment.why_important: Others need to be able to depend on you for relationships and teamwork to function

respect.binary_choice: Treat others with respect, or disrespect them
respect.principle: Respect is foundational to a healthy workplace and community
respect.definition: Treating others with consideration, dignity, and courtesy regardless of differences
teaching_examples: Listening when others speak instead of interrupting
Speaking politely even when you disagree
Acknowledging others' contributions and achievements
respect.why_important: Respect creates environments where everyone can contribute their best

responsibility.binary_choice: Take responsibility for your actions, or make excuses
responsibility.definition: Owning the consequences of your choices and actions, both positive and negative
teaching_examples: Apologizing when you've made a mistake that affects others
Learning from failures instead of blaming external factors
Taking credit appropriately without taking all the credit
responsibility.why_important: Personal growth requires honest self-assessment and learning from mistakes

cooperation.binary_choice: Help others when you can, or ignore those in need
cooperation.principle: Cooperation and support create stronger teams and communities
cooperation.definition: Working together with others and offering assistance when you're able to help
teaching_examples: Offering to help a colleague who is overwhelmed with work
Sharing knowledge and resources that could benefit others
Collaborating effectively on team projects
cooperation.why_important: Communities and organizations thrive when members support each other

empathy.binary_choice: Treat others as you want to be treated, or ignore their feelings
empathy.principle: Empathy leads to better collaboration and conflict resolution
empathy.definition: Understanding and considering how others feel and treating them accordingly
teaching_examples: Considering how your words might affect someone before speaking
Offering comfort to someone who is struggling
Adjusting your communication style to what works best for different people
empathy.why_important: Understanding others' perspectives prevents conflicts and builds stronger relationships

stewardship.binary_choice: Use resources wisely, or waste them
stewardship.principle: Stewardship and sustainability are both ethical and practical
stewardship.definition: Taking care of resources, environment, and shared assets responsibly
teaching_examples: Using only what you need and not being wasteful
Taking care of shared equipment and spaces
Considering the long-term impact of your resource use
stewardship.why_important: Resources are limited and must be preserved for future use and other people

perseverance.binary_choice: Work hard and persist, or give up easily
perseverance.principle: Perseverance is key to achieving goals
perseverance.definition: Continuing to work toward goals despite obstacles, setbacks, or challenges
teaching_examples: Continuing to practice a skill even when progress seems slow
Finding alternative approaches when the first method doesn't work
Maintaining effort toward long-term goals despite short-term difficulties
perseverance.why_important: Most worthwhile achievements require sustained effort over time

personal_responsibility.binary_choice: Keep yourself and your space clean and orderly, or be careless
personal_responsibility.principle: Personal responsibility impacts personal and community wellbeing
personal_responsibility.definition: Taking care of your personal hygiene, belongings, and environment
teaching_examples: Maintaining cleanliness in shared spaces
Keeping your personal workspace organized
Taking care of your health and appearance appropriately
personal_responsibility.why_important: Personal habits affect both your own effectiveness and the comfort of others around you

legal_compliance.binary_choice: Follow laws and rules, or disregard them
legal_compliance.principle: Legal compliance is essential for functioning in society
legal_compliance.definition: Following established laws, regulations, and rules that govern behavior in society
teaching_examples: Following traffic laws when driving
Respecting intellectual property and copyright rules
Following workplace policies and procedures
legal_compliance.why_important: Laws and rules create predictable, safe environments where everyone can function

inclusion.binary_choice: Respect differences and diversity, or exclude and judge
inclusion.definition: Valuing different perspectives, backgrounds, and ways of thinking
teaching_examples: Including different viewpoints in discussions and decisions
Avoiding assumptions based on someone's appearance or background
Creating environments where everyone feels welcome to participate
inclusion.why_important: Diversity of thought and experience leads to better solutions and stronger communities

peaceful_resolution.binary_choice: Resolve conflicts peacefully, or escalate problems
peaceful_resolution.principle: Peaceful conflict resolution is vital for both personal and professional life
peaceful_resolution.definition: Addressing disagreements and conflicts through communication and compromise rather than aggression
teaching_examples: Discussing problems calmly instead of arguing
Looking for win-win solutions when interests conflict
Seeking mediation when direct resolution isn't working
peaceful_resolution.why_important: Peaceful resolution preserves relationships and creates sustainable solutions

attendance_punctuality.habit: Successful students come to class every day, on time
attendance_punctuality.definition: Consistently showing up and being present when expected
teaching_examples: Arriving to class before it starts, ready to learn
Planning your schedule to avoid conflicts with class time
Communicating in advance if you absolutely must be absent
attendance_punctuality.why_important: Learning builds on previous lessons - missing class means missing foundation knowledge

resourcefulness.habit: Successful students know how to determine what they are supposed to do and use the tools to access their work and resources
resourcefulness.definition: Taking initiative to find information and understand requirements independently
teaching_examples: Reading the syllabus and assignment instructions carefully
Learning how to navigate the learning management system
Asking specific questions when you've tried to find answers first
resourcefulness.why_important: Self-directed learning skills transfer to all areas of life and work

excellence_mindset.habit: Successful students do not settle for good enough, they strive to do their best work with every assignment and are constantly asking themselves if they are learning
excellence_mindset.definition: Maintaining high personal standards and focusing on learning rather than just completion
teaching_examples: Reviewing your work before submitting to see if you can improve it
Asking yourself 'What did I learn from this?' after each assignment
Seeking feedback to understand how to do better next time
excellence_mindset.why_important: Excellence becomes a habit that serves you throughout life

academic_integrity.habit: Successful students refuse to cheat or plagiarize or share their answers with other students, opting instead to redirect to the teacher or to scaffold their classmates if they are confident in their own understanding
academic_integrity.definition: Maintaining honesty in academic work and helping others learn rather than giving them answers
teaching_examples: Explaining concepts to classmates rather than just giving them answers
Citing sources properly when using others' ideas
Asking the teacher for help instead of copying from others
academic_integrity.why_important: Academic integrity ensures you actually learn and develops trustworthiness

zero_tolerance.habit: Successful students do not plan for or accept zeros, they do all their work to the best of their ability and turn it in on time
zero_tolerance.definition: Taking responsibility for completing all assignments and managing time effectively
teaching_examples: Planning ahead so you have time to complete assignments well
Starting assignments early rather than waiting until the last minute
Communicating with teachers if you're struggling before the deadline
zero_tolerance.why_important: Consistency in effort leads to consistent learning and success

grade_awareness.habit: Successful students always are aware of their grade and know how to interpret it and how their current work affects it
grade_awareness.definition: Actively monitoring academic progress and understanding how grades reflect learning
teaching_examples: Checking grades regularly and understanding what they mean
Calculating how upcoming assignments will affect your overall grade
Identifying patterns in your performance to improve study strategies
grade_awareness.why_important: Self-awareness about progress enables you to make informed decisions about where to focus effort

respect_for_authority.habit: Successful students honor their teachers and other adults
respect_for_authority.definition: Showing respect and appreciation for those who are invested in your learning and development
teaching_examples: Listening when teachers are speaking and following instructions
Speaking respectfully even when you disagree or are frustrated
Recognizing that teachers want you to succeed and are there to help
respect_for_authority.why_important: Respectful relationships create better learning environments for everyone

learning_values.habit: Successful students value learning in themselves and others and realize it to be the most important duties of children as members of a free society
learning_values.definition: Understanding that education is both a privilege and a responsibility in a democratic society
teaching_examples: Encouraging classmates who are struggling rather than making fun of them
Understanding that your education prepares you to contribute to society
Appreciating the opportunity to learn and grow intellectually
learning_values.why_important: Education is the foundation of personal freedom and democratic participation
